body:
I didn't find how to do this. 
This argument depends on how will you use this library.
The rule is: 
- If this library is a part of \_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to **False**.
- If this library will be used in a cc_binary, which is dynamic linked to \_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to **True**.
- If this library is only available on non-Windows systems(e.g.Linux), either value is ok.

Itself doesn't know such information.
body_html:
I didn't find how to do this.
This argument depends on how will you use this library.
The rule is:

  • If this library is a part of _pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to False.
  • If this library will be used in a cc_binary, which is dynamic linked to _pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to True.
  • If this library is only available on non-Windows systems(e.g.Linux), either value is ok.

Itself doesn't know such information.
body_text:
I didn't find how to do this.
This argument depends on how will you use this library.
The rule is:

If this library is a part of _pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to False.
If this library will be used in a cc_binary, which is dynamic linked to _pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so, please set it to True.
If this library is only available on non-Windows systems(e.g.Linux), either value is ok.

Itself doesn't know such information.
